cleaned_text: Gabriel Cousens This article may present Gabriel Kenneth Cousens |Born| Kenneth Gabriel Cousens May 14, 1943 |Education|[Homeopath](/wiki/Homeopath) [Homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy), [raw foodism](/wiki/Raw_foodism) Gabriel (born May 14, 1943) is an American [homeopath](/wiki/Homeopath), rabbi [[1]](#cite_note-1) and practitioner of [holistic medicine](/wiki/Holistic_health). In 1976, Cousens legally changed his name from Kenneth Gabriel Cousens to Gabriel. Cousens advocates [live foods therapy](/wiki/Raw_foodism), a [nutritional](/wiki/Nutritional) regimen which he says can cure [diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes), [[2]](#cite_note-GNA-2) depression [[3]](#cite_note-3) [[4]](#cite_note-4) and other chronic [degenerative diseases](/wiki/Degenerative_disease). He is the founder of the "Essene Order of Light", a spiritual organization based upon teachings from the Jewish [Kabbalah](/wiki/Kabbalah), the [Torah](/wiki/Torah), and modern interpretations of the [Essenes](/wiki/Essenes). The Essenes are a mystical group from the second century B.C.E. who lived in community, eschewed materialism and grew their own food. The modern Essene movement was founded by [Edmond Bordeaux Szekely](/wiki/Edmond_Bordeaux_Szekely), a religious scholar who promoted a simple holistic lifestyle of meditation and raw vegan eating and published several books on the Essenes in the early 20th century. [[5]](#cite_note-5) Essene Order of Light is taught by Cousens at "Tree of Life Foundation," an organization directed by Cousens and headquartered at its "Tree of Life Rejuvenation Center" in [Patagonia, Arizona](/wiki/Patagonia,_Arizona). [[6]](#cite_note-Melton-6) [[7]](#cite_note-Innes-7) Cousens has authored nine books and tours internationally promoting his ideas on food and his spiritual beliefs. [[8]](#cite_note-8) Early life and education[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Gabriel_Cousens&action=edit§ion=1)] Cousens grew up in [Highland Park, Illinois](/wiki/Highland_Park,_Illinois). [[9]](#cite_note-Condor1994-9) As a freshman at Amherst College, he designed a heart lung machine and spent two summers doing leukemia research. [[10]](#cite_note-football-10) He graduated from [Amherst College](/wiki/Amherst_College) in 1965 with a B.A. in biology, where he was a football lineman/guard/middle linebacker and co-captain of the 1964 football team. [[11]](#cite_note-11) That year he received a [National Football Foundation](/wiki/National_Football_Foundation) National Scholar-Athlete Award. [[10]](#cite_note-football-10) He earned his [medical degree](/wiki/Medical_degree) from [Columbia Medical School](/wiki/Columbia_Medical_School) in 1969, and he completed his residency in [psychiatry](/wiki/Psychiatry) in 1973. [[9]](#cite_note-Condor1994-9) [[12]](#cite_note-Bio-12)[ [self-published source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources)] Cousens says he switched to a [vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian) diet around age 30, [[9]](#cite_note-Condor1994-9) after which he began teaching meditation. In 1974 he went to India to study with the swami [Muktananda](/wiki/Muktananda) (1908-1982), staying for seven years. [[13]](#cite_note-13) He returned to the United States in 1981 and studied Kabbalah and the Essenes, becoming ordained in 1988. [[6]](#cite_note-Melton-6) Tree of Life Foundation and Rejuvenation Center[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Gabriel_Cousens&action=edit§ion=2)] Cousens founded the Essene Order of Light in 1992, [[6]](#cite_note-Melton-6) and the following year he established the Tree of Life Foundation as a federal tax-exempt religious organization. The Tree of Life Rejuvenation Center, located in [Patagonia, Arizona](/wiki/Patagonia,_Arizona), [[14]](#cite_note-14) was founded in 1994 as a health retreat which offers raw food education, [[15]](#cite_note-15) fasting, and nutrition.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Cousens is an ordained [Rabbi](/wiki/Rabbi) [[16]](#cite_note-16) and offers workshops on spiritual Judaism. [[17]](#cite_note-17) His newest book, Torah as a Guide to Enlightenment, published through North Atlantic Books, is a commentary on the Torah from a [Kabbalistic](/wiki/Kabbalistic) perspective. Cousens founded a not for profit organization called the Essene Order of Light which teaches "modern [Essene](/wiki/Essene) living". [[18]](#cite_note-18) [[19]](#cite_note-19) He outlined his philosophy in his book Creating Peace By Being Peace. [[20]](#cite_note-20) Cousens has advocated a nutritionally based raw food diet for babies and children. [[21]](#cite_note-21) He instituted a study of the medical history of infants and children and advocates for raw food education. [[22]](#cite_note-22) A 2009 documentary, Simply Raw, followed six people with [diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes) who go through a thirty-day raw vegan program in an attempt to cure their disease with a raw food diet and without drugs. [[23]](#cite_note-welte-23) Surgeon and alternative medicine critic [David Gorski](/wiki/David_Gorski) said that Cousens and the film both grossly misrepresented the modern medical approach to diabetes. Gorski described Cousens works as promoting [vitalism](/wiki/Vitalism) and other discredited principles. [[24]](#cite_note-:0-24) Legal actions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Gabriel_Cousens&action=edit§ion=3)] In 1994, California revoked his license to practice for "excessive prescribing", but based on a form of plea bargain this revocation was stayed for three years probation. [[25]](#cite_note-25) In consequence of the California decision, New York also required him to return his license. [[26]](#cite_note-Log_In_2014-26) Cousens' license in California was later reinstated, but not in New York. Because of this, he is not eligible for a [medical license](/wiki/Medical_license) in Arizona. [[27]](#cite_note-phoenixnews1-27) In 1998, 57-year-old Charles Levy of New Jersey died after being treated at the center over a five-day period. The cause of death was determined by the [Santa Cruz County](/wiki/Santa_Cruz_County,_Arizona) Medical Examiner, who along with the Arizona Medical Board attributed the death to a [gas gangrene](/wiki/Gas_gangrene) infection caused by "bovine adrenal fluid" injections given by Cousens as part of a treatment for [fatigue](/wiki/Fatigue_(medical)). [[27]](#cite_note-phoenixnews1-27) [[28]](#cite_note-sandal-28) [[29]](#cite_note-azcentral1-29) The autopsy also [encephalomyelitis](/wiki/Encephalomyelitis), and [coronary atherosclerosis](/wiki/Coronary_atherosclerosis). [[28]](#cite_note-sandal-28) Levy's son said that his father was healthy, able to run three miles, not overweight, and had no [high blood pressure](/wiki/High_blood_pressure) at the time of his visit to the spa, and the family sued for [malpractice](/wiki/Malpractice). [[27]](#cite_note-phoenixnews1-27) Cousens settled the suit for an undisclosed amount paid to the family. [[27]](#cite_note-phoenixnews1-27) The case came up before the Arizona Board of Homeopathic Medical Examiners in 2001. Despite the medical examiner's report and testimony, then Board Chairman Bruce Shelton said he "found no medical fault with Dr. Cousens' care of" Levy and the board found "no homeopathic law" in Cousens' treatment. [[27]](#cite_note-phoenixnews1-27) [[29]](#cite_note-azcentral1-29) Cousens argued that the medical examiner had misdiagnosed the cause of death, which he said was toxic shock unrelated to the injections, a claim that the Levy family attorney called "outrageous".
